text.p: These are the leading stories in he Belgrde press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified them nor does it vouch for their accuracy.

- Jovan Zebic, deputy Yugoslav prime minister, said devaluation of dinar was out of the question. Firm and long-term government's commitment is to maintain stable currency and prices and to further liberalise foreign trade.
- Final Yugoslav federal and local elections results expected on Thursday.
- Vojislav Seselj, leader of the Serb Radical Party, advised its supporters not to vote for the left in the second round of elections.
- Mile Isakov, newly elected parliament member for the coalition Vojvodina, said it was definitly clear now that autonomy (of the Serbian northern province of Vojvodina) was the main option.

- John Shattuck, assistant U.S state secretary, on visit to Belgrade on Wednesday expected to meet Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic and discuss extradiction of war criminals charged for war crimes in Vukovar.
- One third of Yugoslav citizens are poor and 650,000 of them can be qualified as extremely poor, Yugoslav Red Cross said.
- Montenegrin President Momir Bulatovic announces charges against certain opposition leaders for slander against the republican leadership.
- IBM London and Vobex of Novi Sad sign one-year agreement for marketing IBM computers in Yugoslavia.
- Germany's M.A.N. concludes agreement with STM of Belgrade on imports and servicing of M.A.N. trucks in Yugoslavia.

- Continuing growth of food prices still one of the biggest problems for Yugoslavs. Price of consumer basket of 60 food and drink items for a family of four rose to 1,476.78 dinars in October from 1,409.14 dinars the previous month. -- Belgrade Newsroom ++381 11 222 4254
